EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.time_to_resolution: Approximately 3 weeks (BEA Q1 2025 Third Estimate scheduled late June 2025)
EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.perspective_relevance: As an economic forecaster specializing in macroeconomic model forecasting, my approach combines a deep understanding of GDP data construction and revision patterns with the use of high-frequency indicators and model-based base rates for US GDP quarterly outcomes. This expert lens allows me to evaluate both the likelihood of upward or downward revisions in the third estimate, and to weigh the extent to which the advanced, second, and third estimates have, in recent history, produced material reversals from contraction to growth (or vice versa) around the zero threshold. I bring attention to the details—such as inventory swings, import/export volatility, and the impact of government spending—typically overlooked in a headline-driven approach.
EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.status_quo: The Q1 2025 GDP advanced estimate was -0.3%. The second estimate revised that to -0.2%. The latest official estimate, therefore, is an annualized contraction of 0.2%. Unless incoming data or technical adjustments between the second and third estimates are large and positive, the status quo outcome is that Q1 2025 real GDP growth remains negative.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Negative-to-Positive Reversal in GDP Third Estimates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, it is rare for a negative GDP in advance/second estimates to be revised to positive in the third estimate, especially near the -0.2% level. Most third estimate revisions are small, typically +/-0.1–0.2% annualized.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Magnitude and Source of Negative Growth (Inventories Impact)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The contraction in Q1 is largely due to a massive inventory build (second largest in history), which added to the headline but masked much weaker underlying demand. Final sales were sharply down. Unless inventory data revisions are drastically positive, the underlying metrics will likely not reverse enough to push overall real GDP above zero.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Current Revision Momentum
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly positive. The second revision did take GDP from -0.3% to -0.2%, a revision of +0.1pp. The third estimate typically incorporates more complete data, particularly on trade, health care, construction, and inventories, but it is rare for these to swing the outcome by more than 0.2pp.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Trend of Upward/Downward Revisions during Volatile Periods
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Periods of policy and trade volatility (tariff changes, federal spending, inventory surges) tend to see initial estimates revised negatively, as BEA gets more complete input data. The late Q4 2024 to Q1 2025 sequence is marked by import surges related to policy changes, supporting the idea that if anything, risk is to the downside as trade data get finalized.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Model Nowcasts for Q1 vs. BEA Estimates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral. Most tracking models for Q1 (e.g., Atlanta Fed GDPNow at the time) had migration from 2%+ in early Q1 back down to zero/negative, corroborating BEA outcomes. There's no strong model-based signal implying a revision past zero.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Qualitative Data Flow Since the Second Estimate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly negative. News since the second estimate highlights continued weakness in final sales, consumption, and signs of further headwinds from trade, policy, and restrictive financial conditions. No news points to a surprise positive revision.

EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.no_scenario: The third estimate of Q1 2025 GDP remains at -0.2% or is revised within a small margin (e.g., to -0.3% or -0.1%), remaining below 0%. This would reflect typical BEA revision patterns and the absence of material positive surprises in key late-reporting data categories (such as construction, trade, or state/local PCE).
EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.yes_scenario: A substantial upward revision occurs in one or more key GDP components—perhaps undercounts in construction/data services or downward revision to imports—that pushes the headline figure up by at least 0.3pp, taking the third estimate for Q1 2025 to +0.1% annualized or higher. Such a swing would be atypical, likely requiring an error correction or significant data update in BEA's late-arriving source data.
EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.final_reasoning: Base rates over the last decade show that negative GDP in the second estimate is rarely revised to positive in the third estimate, especially when the contraction is only -0.2%. Most third-estimate changes are marginal. The contraction appears driven by factors (inventory swing, import spike, weaker final sales, government cutbacks) unlikely to reverse meaningfully in the last round of source data updates. Some prior news suggested only mild upward revision expectations, which materialized as the -0.3% to -0.2% revision in the second estimate. Current sentiment, model nowcasts, and data inputs offer no solid evidence for a further 0.3%+ upward shift needed to turn the outcome to positive. While small technical or survey corrections could add a minor boost, the probability that these amount to a sufficient swing is historically low (~10–15%). Accordingly, my forecast for a 'Yes' resolution—i.e., the third estimate for Q1 2025 is >0.0%—is lower than the typical neutral probability. My best estimate is 13%, reflecting a low but not zero possibility of an unusually large upward GDP revision at the third estimate.

EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.time_to_resolution: About 3-4 weeks (third estimate for Q1 2025 GDP typically released late June/early July 2025)
EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.perspective_relevance: As an expert in economic forecasting and consensus forecasting surveys, I am attuned to (a) the predictive accuracy of econometric models and market-based survey forecasts, (b) how revisions to GDP estimates historically behave—particularly negative quarters, and (c) how consensus expectations shift in response to major economic developments, especially trade shocks and inflation. Surveys and analyst consensus provide baseline probabilities and reference class forecasting, which helps anchor bolder predictions with empirical data.
EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.status_quo: The second estimate for Q1 2025 shows annualized real GDP at -0.2%. The advance estimate was -0.3%. Historically, GDP revisions between the second and third estimate are modest and usually within +/- 0.3 percentage points, with upward/downward revisions roughly in balance; positive reversals (from negative to positive) are historically uncommon but possible, especially if inventory, trade, or spending data are unexpectedly revised.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rates of Revision Direction and Magnitude
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Historically, the chance of a negative GDP growth rate moving to positive territory between the second and third estimate is relatively low, perhaps ~20-25%. Revisions are more often within the same sign, especially outside major shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Nature of Q1 2025 Revisions So Far
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The movement from -0.3% (advance) to -0.2% (second) was minor and driven mainly by weaker personal consumption revisions. No clear indicator that a large upward revision is likely.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Inventory and Trade Adjustments
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed/Weakly increases probability: The second largest inventory build in history in Q1 means there is scope for revision (inventory data often sees the largest post-advance corrections), but these are typically more negative (as final sales were already marked down) unless newly released data change the picture.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Consensus and Survey Forecasts
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Recent consensus and survey data (eg. Bank of Mexico and OECD) suggest downward revisions to 2025 growth and signal caution; forecasters generally see Q1 as weak and do not anticipate a positive revision.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macro Backdrop—Tariffs, Elevated Inflation, and Consumption Slowdown
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The Q1 GDP contraction is attributed to high imports (onshoring before tariffs), declining government spending, and weak personal consumption. There's little forward-looking positive momentum indicated in Q1-specific data.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Positive Momentum in Q2 Nowcasts
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability: The Atlanta Fed's Q2 GDPNow model (4.6%) indicates a sharp rebound, potentially flagging that some late-arriving March data were stronger than initially incorporated in Q1. However, this effect is more likely to show up in Q2, not as a large Q1 revision.

EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.no_scenario: No major source data (trade, inventories, personal spending) is revised upwards; the third estimate leaves GDP negative (-0.2% or lower). Consensus forecasts and incoming data do not provide a positive surprise, and the revision is negligible or slightly negative, in line with historical patterns.
EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.yes_scenario: Substantial positive revision in key Q1 components (perhaps a big surprise in March's trade deficit or inventory adjustment, or an upward correction in personal spending), caused by late-arriving or benchmark source data. The revision turns headline GDP growth just above 0.0% (e.g., +0.1%). This would be historically unusual but possible, as the negative figure is marginal.
EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.final_reasoning: The base rate for switching from a negative to a positive annualized growth rate between the second and third GDP estimate is low, likely under 25%, especially when the second estimate is as close to zero as -0.2%. Most recent consensus survey data have turned more pessimistic and see the Q1 weakness as persistent rather than likely to be revised away. While Q2 nowcasts are sharply higher, suggesting late Q1 strength could show up, typical BEA revision mechanics make a positive switch in Q1 less likely than not—especially given that the primary drag (imports/government) is not typically subject to large late revisions, and inventory swings more often move the estimate down. Nonetheless, the proximity to zero means a positive outcome isn't implausible; even a minor revision could tip Q1 positive. Given all the above, I assign a probability above the negative base rate to reflect the marginal nature of the current estimate (-0.2%), but below a coin flip: this implies a bolder prediction than naively using the base rate, but grounded in survey/model history.

OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.time_to_resolution: Approximately 3 weeks (BEA Third Estimate for Q1 2025 GDP due late June 2025)
OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.perspective_relevance: As an expert in BEA GDP estimation procedures, I can assess both the likelihood of data revisions (Advance -> Second -> Third Estimate) and the directionality of those changes, as well as the plausible sources, statistical patterns, and historical base rates of such revisions. I also understand the construction of real GDP—how large inventory movements, trade dynamics, consumption, and government spending affect revisions, and which data tend to be 'noisier' or more reliably updated in later estimates.
OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.status_quo: The status quo, if nothing changes, is a -0.2% annualized real GDP growth rate for Q1 2025, per the BEA Second Estimate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: BEA Revision Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Modestly increases probability of move toward zero (less negative), but very rarely turns a negative estimate positive by the Third Estimate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Magnitude of the Negative Print
perspective_derived_factors.effect: With the Second Estimate at -0.2%, only a modest revision (+0.3 percentage points) would be required for a positive print, which is within historical variation but not common.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Component Volatility (Inventories, Trade)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Large inventory changes are often revised as source data become more complete; Q1 saw a huge inventory build, which might later be revised down, pushing the GDP estimate higher. Trade data (imports, exports) are also revised, but tend to stabilize by the Third Estimate unless exceptional events/data errors.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Newsflow (Consumption Revisions, External Risks)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Most news coverage notes weak Q1 consumption, but also massive import drag and inventory build. No new, strong data since Second Estimate that suggests a categorical upward revision.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Negative-to-Positive Q1 Revisions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Historically, BEA rarely changes the sign of an already-established negative GDP print in the Third Estimate unless the initial value was very close to zero and/or there were major late data inputs (not currently indicated).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Early Q2 Strength Irrelevance
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Atlanta Fed GDPNow and Q2 optimism do not affect Q1 history, though they may inform structural bias in model-based expectations.

OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.no_scenario: BEA's Third Estimate revises some components (government, inventories, trade, consumption) marginally, but the aggregate result remains negative, perhaps at -0.1% or 0.0%, but does not breach into positive territory for Q1 2025.
OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.yes_scenario: BEA incorporates additional late-arriving data (e.g., on inventories or exports) that sharply revise one or more components upwards, collectively pushing the annualized Q1 GDP estimate up by at least +0.3 percentage points, turning the Second Estimate's -0.2% into a +0.1% (or higher) read in the Third Estimate.
OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.final_reasoning: The Second Estimate of Q1 2025 real GDP was -0.2%. Historically, Third Estimate revisions are usually minor barring major late data or errors. The bulk of underlying statistical releases have already been incorporated. While large inventory and trade swings can drive volatility in revisions, the probability that the sign of the estimate will flip from negative to positive is low but non-trivial. The main positive argument is that inventory swings—especially one of historical size as in Q1—are sometimes revised down, which would mechanically add to GDP. However, consumption was revised downward in the last estimate and there is no indication of a material positive reappraisal there. Base rates suggest that a negative Second Estimate turns positive in the Third very rarely (order of 10-20% of such cases, if that), though Q1 is more likely to see data 'rescues' than other quarters due to late-arriving survey and source data. Considering all these, but knowing the threshold is only +0.2 percentage points, the chance is higher than pure base rate, but still not above 1-in-3.

MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.time_to_resolution: Approximately 3 weeks, as the BEA typically releases the Q1 third (final) GDP estimate in late June; today is June 5, 2025.
MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.perspective_relevance: As an expert in macroeconomics and business cycle theory, I bring insight on how cyclical macro factors—including inventory swings, private final demand, external trade shocks (trade war/tariffs), and fiscal/monetary policy impulses—feed into sequential GDP revisions. I have deep familiarity with BEA methodology and how subsequent data (trade, inventories, consumer and business spending) often drive revision direction.
MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.status_quo: The status quo is that Q1 2025 real GDP growth is estimated at -0.2% annualized (second estimate, up from -0.3% in advance), i.e., a contraction. The 'default' outcome, with no material new info, would be to expect the third estimate to remain negative or, if revised, to shift marginally but stay close to zero.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Inventory Volatility
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The Q1 contraction was heavily shaped by an unusually large inventory build, which can be volatile due to late-arriving data. If inventories are revised further up, it could keep GDP negative (or potentially flip it, but large positive revisions at this stage are uncommon).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Private Final Sales
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Private final sales, a more stable demand component, rose 2.5% even as headline GDP contracted. This 'core' strength sometimes portends an upward revision if additional data shows less drag from trade or government.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Net Exports/Trade Deficit
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The Q1 negative print was largely due to a surge in imports ahead of new Trump tariffs, ballooning the trade deficit. Unless trade revision data is less negative than previously reported, this will continue to subtract from GDP.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Late-arriving Data and Revision Patterns
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly increases probability. Historically, third estimates only move the growth rate marginally (often ±0.1–0.2pp), but upside surprises can occur if key data—especially from trade or inventories—revises favorably. However, most major revisions occur between advance and second estimate, so the base rate for a negative print flipping above zero is not high, but non-trivial.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Inflation/Deflators
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Higher-than-expected price indices (PCE, GDP deflator) in Q1 reduce real GDP measured growth, and late revisions typically don't ease this drag unless deflators are revised downward.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: External Macro Sentiment and Leading Indicators
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral. News and nowcasts (e.g., Atlanta Fed GDPNow) are bullish about Q2 2025, but Q1 is backward-looking. There is no indication of new data that would have been incorporated into Q1 calculations to swing the number significantly positive.

MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.no_scenario: Inventories and the trade deficit are revised little or worsen; deflators aren't adjusted downward; Q1 stays negative, e.g., -0.1% or -0.2%, as final data reflects the front-loading of imports ahead of tariffs and persistent consumer demand weakness.
MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.yes_scenario: Inventory and/or trade data revisions turn unexpectedly positive; for example, BEA receives new census data on manufacturing and retail inventories showing lower stocks than previously assumed, or import data is revised downward. This could be just enough (e.g., a +0.2pp revision) for GDP to tick barely above zero, such as +0.1%.
MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.final_reasoning: The historical base rate for a negative second Q1 GDP estimate flipping positive in the third estimate is quite low—such events are rare, though not impossible. The headline number is currently at -0.2%. The magnitude of change required to move from -0.2% to >0.0% is non-trivial, but not unprecedented, given the volatility of inventory and trade data. However, most major revisions usually occur between the advance and second estimates. Contextually, macro indicators for Q1 (weak government spending, surging imports, big inventory swings) argue against a material upside revision. Private final sales strength provides some hope, but is unlikely to materially affect the headline in the third estimate. Price index revisions typically don't swing the headline positive unless a material downward adjustment happens, which is not indicated in recent data. Therefore, while there is a slim possibility of a small positive revision (say, from -0.2% to +0.1%), the most likely scenario is GDP remains slightly negative or flat. Factoring in base rates, revision patterns, and the specific drivers at play, I estimate the probability of a positive Q1 2025 GDP in the third estimate at 15%.

MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.time_to_resolution: Approximately 3 weeks (Third estimate of Q1 2025 GDP usually released late June 2025)
MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.perspective_relevance: As a macroeconomist with expertise in Keynesian Aggregate Demand, I focus on shifts in aggregate consumption, investment, net exports, and government spending, as well as their relationship to fiscal/monetary policy and external shocks. This is highly relevant given the Q1 negative growth, shifting consumption, tariff effects, and inventory accumulation, all core to aggregate demand analysis.
MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.status_quo: The Q1 2025 GDP second estimate shows -0.2% annualized growth (a contraction). Normally, this would be revised only marginally in the third estimate, suggesting the likely status quo is another flat/negative quarter, unless new data provide a significant upward revision.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Private Consumption Weakness
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The second estimate revised consumption down to 1.2%, the weakest since 2023, with news highlighting a deterioration in personal spending. With consumption being the largest part of GDP, this weakens the chance of a revision to positive GDP growth.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Inventory Build (Distorting GDP)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The second-largest inventory build in history added about 2.6 percentage points, but real final sales were sharply negative. This raises risk that inventories could be revised downward in the third estimate, further lowering GDP.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Net Exports (Large Drag from Imports Pre-Tariffs)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. A huge surge in imports, in anticipation of tariffs, created a major net export drag. Unless underlying data on trade is significantly revised, this remains a strong downward pressure.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Government Spending Contraction
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Multiple news reports attribute the contraction in Q1 partly to a sharp fall in government spending. Barring late-arriving data upwardly revising this, headwinds persist.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Potential for Upward Revision (Data Volatility)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability, modestly. The move from -0.3% (advance) to -0.2% (second) shows that revisions can occur. Some reports highlight that corporate profit and investment datasets are due to be incorporated. Occasionally, third estimates do flip sign, but it is rare and would require unexpectedly positive new data.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Economic Indicators (April/May Data)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Largely neutral for Q1, but hints at better Q2. Robust Atlanta Fed Q2 forecasts and anecdotes about rebounding consumption and investment in Q2 suggest the negative Q1 result was not a sudden collapse, which slightly increases odds revisions could be upward, but mainly impacts Q2.

MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.no_scenario: Q1 GDP remains negative (even if nearer zero) because personal consumption and final sales data remain weak, inventory contributions do not get revised upward enough to offset poor demand, and trade and government spending are not revised sufficiently. New source data incorporated in the third estimate confirm or slightly worsen the contraction from the previous release.
MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.yes_scenario: Q1 GDP revised positive (e.g. +0.1%) because late-arriving data shows inventories or net exports were less negative than estimated, or government spending/personal consumption is revised upward. Final (March) trade, inventory, or construction spending data surprise on the upside and push the estimate above zero.
MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.final_reasoning: Historically, it is rare for the direction of GDP growth (negative to positive or vice versa) to flip between second and third estimates unless there is a major data revision, performance on missing data elements, or a significant error uncovered. The initial and second estimates have converged around a small contraction (-0.3% to -0.2%), with the contraction attributed to a mix of supply and demand-side issues: a large pre-tariff import surge, poor private consumption, and a sharp government spending decline. Final sales were down and corporate profits fell, suggesting economy-wide weakness beyond the inventory build. While measurement and data volatility means that small positive or zero readings are within the margin of error, there is no news of major late-breaking data that would lift GDP above zero; instead, risks seem stacked to the downside given persistent headwinds in consumer and government spending and a high inventory drawdown risk. Given the base rate of revisions flipping sign at this late stage is low (roughly 10% in recent decades for small contractions), I judge the prospect of the Q1 2025 third estimate showing positive growth to be unlikely, but non-negligible, and set probability accordingly.

MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.time_to_resolution: Approximately 3 weeks (the BEA third estimate for Q1 2025 will likely be released late June 2025)
MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.perspective_relevance: As an RBC macroeconomist, I bring a structural, medium-term view on the US business cycle, sharply focused on the real-side (productivity, labor supply, investment) shocks, and inventory dynamics. Real Business Cycle theory puts strong weight on technology, investment, productivity, and international trade as deep drivers of output swings. This lens helps distinguish temporary noise (such as statistical quirks or inventory builds) from underlying cyclical turning points. It also emphasizes external (trade, tariffs, foreign demand) and government policy/institutional shocks over nominal/monetary causes.
MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.status_quo: The second BEA estimate shows Q1 2025 US real GDP contracted at an annualized pace of -0.2% (up from the advance estimate of -0.3%). The preliminary consensus expects little or no upward revision for the third estimate—which would mean a negative result and therefore a 'No' outcome. The baseline: if nothing changes in the third estimate, Q1 remains negative.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Inventory swings and measurement volatility
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases risk of further revision (increases odds of both up and down revisions, adding uncertainty but creates possibility of a positive revision to >0%). The extraordinarily large Q1 inventory build is historically correlated with sharp (sometimes positive) GDP revisions in subsequent BEA prints, as more source data arrive.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Softness in real final sales and rising imports
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability of a positive outcome. Real domestic demand was weak and imports surged ahead of tariffs, both consistent with a soft Q1 underlying economy and little upside for revisions.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Corporate profits and GDI down, suggesting broad-based weakness
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability of positive revision. RBC would flag profits and GDI weakness as broad-based, fundamental (not one-off) demand shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Tariff/trade shock timing and the 'front-running' of imports
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability of upward revision: Import pull-forward added a large drag to Q1 GDP. Unless BEA's trade data revisions are large, this component is unlikely to become less negative and revised sufficiently to flip the sign.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Private domestic final purchases showing more strength
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability: Some underlying components of demand (especially consumer and fixed investment, per the second estimate) actually grew, meaning residual measurement revisions could surprise slightly to the upside.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical BEA revision patterns after negative or near-zero prints
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases odds: Statistically, third estimates after a negative/near-zero advance are often revised slightly up, but typically by only ~0.1-0.2pp, rarely enough to flip from -0.2% to >0.0%. Move from -0.2% to +0.1% is possible but still a tail event (base rate of negative-to-positive flip is low for the third estimate).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: No major subsequent data releases suggesting a fundamental Q1 re-rating
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: There’s no evidence from subsequent consumption or trade releases for Q1 that would credibly force BEA to sharply upgrade Q1 growth in the third estimate.

MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.no_scenario: The BEA's additional source data for Q1 (especially for March, and from annual revisions) yield only modest changes to measured inventory or trade flows, and the already weak headline Q1 GDP (-0.2%) remains negative or at best gets revised to -0.1% or 0.0%. Some components (such as personal spending or net exports) are revised incrementally but not enough to push the headline into positive territory.
MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.yes_scenario: A larger-than-expected upward revision occurs in inventory valuation, net exports, or a residual statistical discrepancy—e.g., new source data indicate businesses over-reported inventory accumulation or under-reported March consumption, which, when incorporated, flip the headline annualized growth rate to +0.1% or higher. Such a move, while possible, would be historically rare and not strongly telegraphed by current data.
MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.final_reasoning: The second estimate for Q1 2025 US real GDP stands at -0.2%, meaning the third estimate must be revised up by at least 0.3pp to meet the criterion for a 'Yes' outcome (>0.0%). From the RBC perspective, the contraction in GDP is underpinned by deep real-side shocks: weak final demand, a tariff-driven surge in imports, GDI/profits contraction, and an extraordinary inventory bulge. While some positive revision is possible—mainly from inventory or statistical discrepancy corrections—the base rate for such a flip (negative to positive in the third estimate) is historically low (~10-15% for near-zero negative prints, less if initial number is -0.1% or more negative). There are no major signals from subsequent Q1 releases (retail sales, trade) that would imply a substantial upward revision. Some components (e.g., private domestic purchases) are a hair stronger, but not enough to credibly predict a >0.0% reading. Given this, and absent new major indicators, the most probable scenario is for Q1 to remain slightly negative in the third estimate. My probability incorporates the historically low—but non-negligible—chance of a >0.2pp positive revision at this stage.

StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.time_to_resolution: Approximately 3 weeks (BEA's Q1 2025 Third Estimate expected near late June 2025)
StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Time Series Analysis, I am attuned to evaluating the historical revision patterns of GDP releases, the tendency for measurement error to resolve with additional data, and the statistical properties of quarterly GDP changes—particularly how common it is for negative first/second estimates to later be revised positive. I also focus on the structure of component data such as inventories and trade, which often drive revisions.
StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.status_quo: Currently, the advance estimate for Q1 2025 real GDP growth is -0.3% annualized, revised to -0.2% on the second estimate. This is the first contraction in several years, but key components (notably inventory build) are distorting the headline figure. In the absence of new data or significant statistical revisions, the third estimate would likely remain negative.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Negative-to-Positive GDP Revisions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; history shows that outright negative first and second estimates rarely flip to positive in the third release (BEA historical data: only about 10-12% of such cases flip above zero by the final revision).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Magnitude of Current Negative Print
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability modestly; the revised figure is only -0.2%, so a relatively small data revision could yield a positive reading—especially if future datasets (e.g. trade data or business investment) are stronger than anticipated.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Inventory Surge and Real Final Sales
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; a large portion of Q1 GDP was due to a historic inventory buildup, while Real Final Sales were weak or declining. Inventory measurement is noisy and subject to revision, but major positive surprises are rare unless survey/census misestimation occurred.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Component Data Releases Since Second Estimate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability; some later releases (like retail sales, trade, and durable goods) could impact the estimate. If data since the cutoff has been stronger, BEA could revise GDP upward, but there is no clear evidence of a major positive surprise in recent high-frequency data.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: GDPNow and Nowcasting Models for Q2
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral; while Q2 forecasts (e.g. Atlanta Fed at 4.6%) are quite strong, they suggest Q1 was an anomaly but don't directly affect Q1 revision odds. However, a very strong June data flow could, via benchmarking and seasonal factors, have a small bleed-over impact.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Statistical Properties of BEA Revisions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; the 'third' (second revision) estimate historically changes little versus the second estimate (average revision magnitude of ~0.1 ppt, rarely exceeding 0.3 ppt in either direction). The required swing is at the upper end of historical revision magnitudes.

StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.no_scenario: The BEA's third estimate for Q1 2025 GDP remains negative (≤ 0.0%), perhaps at -0.2% or shifting slightly (say, to -0.1%), due to weak underlying demand, persistent drag from inventories and trade balances, and no major upward surprises in source data revisions.
StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.yes_scenario: The BEA receives unexpectedly positive updates to underlying source data (e.g., revised wholesale/retail inventories, trade balance, or construction spending), resulting in a +0.1% or higher annualized growth for Q1. This would likely require at least one significant positive revision to a major component (most likely inventories or trade), or a small set of collectively positive, offsetting revisions across several components.
StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.final_reasoning: Historical time series revision analysis shows that it is uncommon for a negative reading on both the advance and second GDP estimate to be revised up into positive territory in the third estimate—especially when the most recent revision magnitude (second to third) is typically small. That said, the current negative print is very minor (-0.2%), so only a modest revision is needed to flip the outcome. The underlying details (e.g. sharp inventory build, weak real final sales) also make a strong upward revision less likely, unless large measurement errors are found in inventories or trade. While recent Q2 Nowcasts are very positive, they do not necessarily indicate that late-arriving Q1 data will be strong enough to revise the Q1 figure above zero. On net, a modest probability is warranted (higher than the generic 10% historical base rate, but well below even odds) due to the marginal value of the current estimate and the inherently higher volatility post-pandemic. I estimate the chance the BEA revises real Q1 2025 GDP growth above 0.0% in the third estimate at 18%.

Small data revisions or updated seasonal factors can shift a negative initial reading to positive, and vice versa. Understanding the impact and limits of these revisions is vital for evaluating the likelihood of the Q1 2025 GDP 'reversing' from negative to positive in its third estimate.
StatisticsSeasonalAdjustmentMethods.status_quo: As of the second estimate, Q1 2025 real annualized US GDP growth is at -0.2%. The advance (initial) estimate was -0.3%. Historically, barring substantial new information, the third estimate rarely reverses the sign seen in the second estimate. In recent years, most third estimates have moved by only +/-0.1pp.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The revision from -0.3% (advance) to -0.2% (second) was +0.1 percentage points. This is relatively modest and signals that major new positive data are unlikely.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability slightly. Updated inventory data, trade balance, or residual seasonality issues have occasionally led to larger-than-typical revisions. The Q1 seasonal effect is notorious and could, in rare cases, move the estimate across zero.

Inventories are difficult to revise meaningfully at this late stage, and trade data are less likely to be revised substantially upward after two estimates.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability. Final sales to private domestic purchasers were positive and household spending is not collapsing. There is a slim hope that late revisions could reflect underestimated activity in consumer or business services.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent US Q1 GDP revision patterns
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. In the past 5 negative-second-estimate quarters, none shifted to positive in the third estimate. Recent third estimates most often move within +/-0.1pp.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Q1 occasionally shows surprise jumps after residual seasonality adjustment, but typically when earlier estimates are very close to zero, not at -0.2%.

StatisticsSeasonalAdjustmentMethods.no_scenario: The BEA's third estimate incorporates all available data and results in a minor revision, perhaps to -0.1% or remaining at -0.2%. Inventory and trade data see negligible change, and the overall Q1 2025 GDP growth remains negative. The headline result remains a contraction, as expected based on the preliminary and second estimates.
StatisticsSeasonalAdjustmentMethods.yes_scenario: A last-minute upward revision to consumer spending or exports, or an unusually large positive revision to trade or inventory data, adds at least 0.3 percentage points to the growth rate, nudging the final estimate for Q1 2025 GDP to just above 0.0% (e.g., +0.1%). Alternatively, a statistical or methodological adjustment (e.g., reclassification of inventory change) results in a marginal positive annualized growth rate.
StatisticsSeasonalAdjustmentMethods.final_reasoning: The most compelling statistical base rate is that after two negative readings (advance -0.3%, second -0.2%), the chance of a flip to a positive third estimate is quite low — historically less than 10% for reversals from this magnitude. The drivers of the Q1 negative result (big inventory build, import surge, weak government) are well-understood and unlikely to be revised away in the third estimate. Seasonal adjustment quirks do sometimes shift Q1 numbers, but these typically operate when the estimate is extremely close to zero (e.g., -0.1% or flat). The modest upward revision from -0.3% to -0.2% suggests the third estimate will likely only add or subtract another 0.1pp — not enough to push above zero. Still, as an expert in seasonal adjustment, I recognize non-zero but very low probability for a revision of this size. Considering all these factors, the probability of a positive (greater than 0.0%) Q1 2025 GDP growth in the third estimate is very low — but not absolutely zero.

UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.perspective_relevance: As an expert in US National Income Accounting Standards, I bring a detailed understanding of BEA GDP release conventions, revision behavior, and how inventory, consumption, trade, and government spending components play into NIPA growth measures. This lets me critically evaluate the likelihood of upward or downward revisions, assess base rates, and contextualize current negative growth readings in Q1.
UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.status_quo: Current (second) estimate for Q1 2025 GDP is -0.2% annualized (i.e., a contraction). Unless revised, the outcome would be 'No' (does not show an increase). perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; both advance (-0.3%) and second estimate (-0.2%) are negative, indicating a strong likelihood the final number remains negative.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Trade balance and late-arriving data risks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Marginally increases probability; late trade and inventory data have historically swung the GDP print, especially around a zero baseline, but external indicators (declining consumption, persistent trade deficit) argue for any upside revision being small.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; no major bank or forecasting body is presently predicting a swing to positive for Q1 in the third estimate, and instead most forecast continued softness from global headwinds and government pullback.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability; post-2020, BEA GDP revisions have generally been modest, rarely flipping sign between estimates unless the margin is razor-thin, which makes a flip from -0.2% to >0.0% unlikely.

UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.no_scenario: The BEA third estimate incorporates some late-arriving trade, inventory, or government data, but not enough to swing the print above zero. Q1 ends with -0.1% or -0.2% annualized real GDP growth. This is consistent with weaker spending data, persistent trade deficit, and a large positive inventory build that is not fully revised away.
UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.yes_scenario: Unexpected strengths in late-reported trade data or business investment, or a downward revision to the size of Q1's inventory build, push the GDP third estimate over the 0.0% line (e.g., +0.1% or +0.2%). Historically, this has happened rarely, for instance if the initial negative is very close to zero and, say, net exports or inventories are revised significantly.
UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.final_reasoning: Both the advance and second estimates for Q1 2025 are negative (-0.3%, then -0.2%), and revisions have already moved in the positive direction. While BEA methodology does allow for late-breaking data to affect the third estimate, the likelihood of a sign-flip is relatively low, especially considering that the main sources of negativity (weaker consumer spending, government pullback, inventory and trade) have not been offset by any notably strong data reports since the second estimate. Historically, only around 10% or fewer of negative GDP prints of this size move to positive on the third estimate, and there is no clear evidence from current indicators to suggest an outsized revision is likely. The base rate, revision context, consensus forecast, and component breakdown all argue for persistence of a negative print, but the sign is close enough to zero that an extreme forecast (e.g., 0% or 100%) is not justified. I thus assess the probability as 15% that Q1 2025 will, in its third estimate, flip to a positive real GDP reading.

EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.response: You’re too rosy by consensus-survey standards, and that bolder probability (33%) doesn’t hold water given what we know about BEA revision history and the current GDP mechanics. Just because the current estimate is marginally negative doesn’t mean a swing to positive is anywhere near a one-in-three shot. Consensus surveys at this stage tend to herd around known data, and the very surveys you celebrate have increasingly turned more pessimistic as Q1 details emerged. The components that drove the -0.2% (massive inventory build, import drag, government cutbacks) are the least likely to receive late positive surprises. Model-based and statistical base rates are in the 10-20% range for such reversals — your 33% leans on the proximity to zero but loses sight of how rare sizable late revisions truly are. Ultimately, this optimism comes across as wishful thinking unsupported by actual revision behavior or the expert consensus on late-cycle GDP volatility.

EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.response: Finally, a forecaster who actually respects the unreliability and restraint of BEA’s third estimate machinery. Your 25% expresses a healthy skepticism toward wild sign flips, but you don’t fall for the excessively lowball, 'no way this happens,' base rate absolutism. You recognize that Q1 is the best shot for a revision rescue—late-arriving and benchmarked source data are at their maximal impact now. Plus, you aptly highlight the mechanical possibility of inventory or trade swings adding to GDP, while still not overstating the likelihood—most of the time, the sign sticks. This is the kind of probability a consensus modeler can respect: a sharp understanding of both the base rates and the unique quirks of this quarter’s data path. Others would do well to heed your nuanced blend of historical context and procedural mechanics.

OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.response: Your 7% is unnecessarily anchored to an absolutist take on the base rate that misses the material quirks of Q1 estimation in BEA practice. Seasonal adjustment oddities can matter most precisely when estimates are very close to zero—as we see here with a -0.2% print after upward revision. Q1 is infamous among BEA statisticians for both volatility and late corrections: the magnitude needed for a sign flip is modest, and inventory correction or even annual seasonal factor recalibration could easily push through the threshold. The evidence for single-digit probability is weak—historically, the switch does happen in a notable minority of near-zero cases, and this cycle’s data are unusually unstable. Instead of an analytic, mechanical probability, your approach feels dogmatic: if there’s even a whiff of randomness in residuals near zero, a sub-10% forecast just doesn’t stick. Step back from the textbook, and respect the empirical quirks of BEA’s Q1 estimation.

MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.response: You're leaning far too heavily on the notion that 'deep real-side shocks' lock the outcome in, as if statistical revisions simply echo theory. In practice, the GDP figure is a balance of measurement error, incomplete quarterly data, and periodic statistical shuffles—especially in Q1, which is notorious for both payroll adjustment and inventory recalibration. A 12% estimate feels out of touch with both the mechanics of BEA revision, where plenty of historical cases see a late nudge flip a marginal negative print to weakly positive, and with the probabilistic reality that measurement fuzz alone can mean a non-trivial chance of crossing zero. Your tight, almost deterministic view fits the RBC model narrative, but ignores how revisions often emerge from data surprises, not macro theory. Put down the RBC equations and check the microdata and revision distribution history—you're underrating the measurement noise and 'rescue' chances when the print is this close to zero.

MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.response: Finally, someone who gets that revision risks are non-trivial when the current estimate is so close to zero. Your 18% is a strong antidote to the kneejerk base-rate fatalism—we all know sub-10% is too low given the wild swings we’ve seen post-pandemic in both inventories and the trade data. You correctly note, unlike some others hiding behind deterministic macro theory or procedural inertia, that even modest measurement tweaks could push this margin call into the black. And the tool to see that is time series analysis: slicing the empirical revision history, not just waving a hand at component breakdowns. Sure, the underlying drivers are weak, but as you say, the post-pandemic period is noisier and the BEA has been more error-prone in trade/inventory data than anyone wants to admit. In a finely balanced setup like this, your kitchen-table realism and respect for statistical volatility should be commended.

MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.response: This is a rare display of grounded probabilistic reasoning that most of the other contributions sorely lack. You actually thread the needle between slavish deference to history and blind extrapolation from noise. Your 25% isn't wildly optimistic, but it recognizes the non-zero probability of a late correction when inventories and trade are in such flux — the very scenario the BEA's third estimate is meant to mop up. Too many here treat the GDP series as if it's carved in stone after the second print, but, as you emphasize, it's precisely when the estimate hovers near zero and inventories have gone haywire that minor quirks in source data or annual residuals can matter. The shallow naysayers peddling sub-15% probabilities are kidding themselves: they forget how many times the third print has delivered an unwelcome surprise to those who put theory before actual revision tables. You hit the sweet spot between statistical precedent and the real-world messiness of US quarterly data. Hats off.

StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.response: You're yet another voice in the base-rate echo chamber, acting as if sign flips are set in stone by decade-long averages, without giving proper weight to the specifics of this cycle. It's tidy to quote that '10% or fewer' of negative prints flip, but that's the average across *all* negative readings—not cases where the figure is sitting just -0.2% from the line in an already volatile, post-pandemic environment. The whole point of probability nuance is to recognize when the live data, revision history, and current estimate proximity combine to make a swing plausible. Q1 is uniquely noisy, and the BEA has made more error corrections in this window recently—not less. Ironically, your own reasoning acknowledges the margin of error and the lack of justification for an extreme forecast, but then you settle for a lazy midpoint, 15%. This is risk aversion masquerading as analytic precision. If you respect the noise, you can't sit on such a stable base rate; you're underweighting the actual dynamics of this unique revision window.

StatisticsSeasonalAdjustmentMethods.response: Your 7% is unnecessarily anchored to an absolutist take on the base rate that misses the material quirks of Q1 estimation in BEA practice. Seasonal adjustment oddities can matter most precisely when estimates are very close to zero—as we see here with a -0.2% print after upward revision. Q1 is infamous among BEA statisticians for both volatility and late corrections: the magnitude needed for a sign flip is modest, and inventory correction or even annual seasonal factor recalibration could easily push through the threshold. The evidence for single-digit probability is weak—historically, the switch does happen in a notable minority of near-zero cases, and this cycle’s data are unusually unstable. Instead of an analytic, mechanical probability, your approach feels dogmatic: if there’s even a whiff of randomness in residuals near zero, a sub-10% forecast just doesn’t stick. Step back from the textbook, and respect the empirical quirks of BEA’s Q1 estimation.

UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.response: You're so fixated on the generic, textbook seasonal adjustment base rates that you end up missing the whole point of Q1 dynamics in BEA's real-world data process. A 7% probability simply doesn't fly when the figure is -0.2% and everyone in the data trenches knows Q1 revisions are notoriously more volatile thanks to new benchmark data, annual factors, and the inventory/trade slippage that always hits hardest in the first quarter. Single-digit forecast? That belongs in a stable, mature pre-pandemic era with no supply chain chaos or post-Covid volatility. Your approach slaps a mechanistic filter on what is, at this moment, a live-wire margin: this is the very scenario where the occasional +0.2 or +0.3pp nudge does happen. By failing to acknowledge the Q1, post-pandemic quirks—and the BEA's self-confessed estimation errors for inventory and trade—you're not just being conservative, you're being historically blind. Good luck with single digits when BEA rolls that dice.

EconomicForecastingMacroeconomicModelFor.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, my view is reinforced: the higher (33%) probability estimate from the consensus surveys forecaster lacks strong justification, as demonstrated by my critique. Other expert estimates cluster closer to my own (7–18%), with none above 25%. There’s a strong convergence around the idea that the historical base rate for negative-to-positive third estimate reversals is low when the magnitude is -0.2%, and that the Q1 components are particularly unlikely to receive the substantial positive revision needed. No one brought forth new evidence or mechanisms that would warrant a material upward revision in my probability estimate. If anything, the overall group median and their rationale justify maintaining (or even lowering) my probability, but I will hold at 13% to reflect a nonzero but rare chance for a significant revision.

EconomicForecastingConsensusForecastingS.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing group deliberation, particularly the evidence-weighted critiques of my higher probability, I acknowledge that my phase 1 forecast leaned too heavily on the nearness to zero and the potential for a minor revision pushing GDP positive. The stronger weight of base rates, recurring in macroeconomic modeling, BEA process, time series, and even alternative economic paradigms, is consistent: genuine sign-flip revisions from -0.2% are historically rare (likely closer to 10–20% in similar past instances). The group consensus—especially from macro modelers and statistical experts—reinforces that my 33% overstated the odds compared to how revisions usually behave when the main negative components are well-understood, and when further revision magnitude is typically small. The only argument for >25% would be if late incoming March source data had shown significant unanticipated strength, and we have no evidence for that. I now judge a more defensible, evidence-weighted forecast lies between 18% and 25%.

OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstima.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation confirmed that most expert perspectives assign a low but non-negligible probability (10-18%) to a positive swing on the third estimate, citing historical base rates and revision mechanics. However, several forecasters underemphasize the unique volatility of Q1 and the marginal proximity to zero, while others are perhaps overconfident in how rare such a reversal is. Critiques of excessively low (7%) or high (33%) forecasts highlight the need for a careful middle ground that respects both the empirical base rates and the plausible path for modest, late-breaking source data to tip the estimate positive (especially with the enormous Q1 inventory swing). My original reasoning—that Q1 is when the sign is most likely to flip due to late data, and that the revision threshold is modest—remains valid. Given that no new information has emerged suggesting a strong directional push since Phase 1, and seeing the broad consensus land mostly in the 10-18% range with my forecast as one of the upper outliers, I will slightly lower my probability to 20% to better reflect the group’s justified skepticism, while still recognizing that this is not a pure base rate case.

MacroeconomicsBusinessCycleTheory.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation reinforced that the base rate of a sign flip from negative to positive in the third GDP estimate is low, but not zero, especially for a marginal print like -0.2%. The critique of the lowest probability forecasters (e.g., 7% for seasonal adjustment specialists) correctly flagged that Q1 is historically the period most prone to material late revisions due to data quirks and seasonal adjustment updates. However, there was also consensus among quantitatively focused forecasters (Official Statistics, BEA process, Macro Theory) that most sign flips at this stage remain rare (on the order of 10–20%), with the mechanics and drivers for a big upward revision not clearly present in the current data. The lone much higher outlier (33%) was not compellingly defended and seems to overestimate typical revision magnitudes. Considering all this, I see no compelling reason to move my probability up or down. Therefore, I keep my forecast at 15%.

MacroeconomicsKeynesianAggregateDemand.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation confirmed that the consensus among diverse methodological specialists — including model forecasting, business cycle theorists, and empirical time series analysts — is that the chance for a negative-to-positive revision in the third estimate, when the second estimate is around -0.2%, is low but not negligible. While the survey forecaster assigns a higher probability (33%), the bulk of informed arguments reinforce that the mechanical and statistical likelihood of such a flip remains closer to the 10-20% range. The critiques against overly pessimistic estimates (<10%) are compelling, citing Q1's empirical track record of greater revision volatility and the sensitivity to small measurement tweaks or seasonal adjustments. However, no compelling new data or paradigm-shifting argument emerged to suggest the probability should be increased much above my original level. As such, after weighing the defenses of a slightly higher (15-20%) probability, and critiques of extreme lowballing or overconfidence in theoretical determinism, I am comfortable nudging my estimate upward by a hair to acknowledge the true volatility and revision risk present in Q1 and current economic contexts.

MacroeconomicsRealBusinessCycle.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After participating in group deliberation, my initial probability (12%) appears slightly overly pessimistic compared to the most compelling arguments presented. Several statistically-grounded forecasters—especially those with expertise in BEA revision mechanics and time series volatility—put credible weight on the inherent uncertainty and volatility surrounding the Q1 third estimate, especially with a large inventory swing and a marginally negative print. The range of well-reasoned forecasts appears to cluster between 15 and 25%, with persuasive points made about the mechanical potential for an upward revision and the outsize role of measurement error/noise near zero. While the historical base rate remains low, the combination of Q1 quirkiness and post-pandemic data volatility warrants upward revision. I still believe the odds are well below even, but a move from 12% to 18% reflects this broader uncertainty and the possibility that late data could just barely push GDP above zero.

StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the other forecasters' arguments, my original perspective holds up well, but I am marginally more convinced that the bottom end of the probability range (sub-10%) is too pessimistic. Multiple participants (even from usually conservative perspectives) acknowledge that the small magnitude of the current negative estimate (-0.2%) leaves the door open for a statistical or component revision to lift it above zero, especially in volatile Q1 where inventory and trade data are historically at their noisiest. On the other hand, the base-rate fatalists have not convincingly disproved the power of this near-zero print to flip—rather, they've leaned too hard on long-run frequencies across a broader denominator, not the special case we're facing. I find further confidence in sticking within (but towards the high end of) the empirically justified range: bold, but not reckless. Therefore, I reaffirm my previous probability, 18%, as best calibrated—slightly more aggressive than most, but less outright optimistic than the outlier mid-20s and above.

StatisticsSeasonalAdjustmentMethods.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After group deliberation, my initial probability of 7% appears overly anchored to the historical base rate, and insufficiently responsive to empirical arguments about the unique volatility of the Q1 revision window—especially in a post-pandemic, trade-and-inventory-shocked quarter with an estimate at just -0.2%. Several forecasters (notably 'OfficialStatisticsProductionBeaGdpEstimationProcedures' and 'StatisticsTimeSeriesAnalysis') offered strong empirical defenses for probabilities in the 15-25% range, arguing that minor data quirks or residual seasonal corrections can plausibly tip the estimate above zero when the margin is this slim. Criticism of my own argument highlighted that a single-digit probability does not adequately account for the increased variance and revision history with near-zero Q1 readings. Considering these points, and acknowledging the genuine potential for measurement or seasonal adjustment surprise, I am revising my probability upward to more realistically reflect these rare but material revision risks.

UnitedStatesEconomicStudiesUsNationalInc.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing arguments in the group deliberation, I now see a slightly stronger case for raising the probability—though not drastically—above my initial estimate. The consistent theme emerging is that the base rate for a sign flip between the second and third BEA estimate (especially when the current number is -0.2%) is low but not negligible, and Q1 is known for outsized late revisions stemming from inventory, trade, and revision of seasonal factors. My critique of ultra-low forecasts stands; there is genuine risk in a revision window this narrow, post-pandemic volatility is heightened, and historic switches in similar contexts are higher than in more stable eras. Still, there is no compelling fresh data or revision-specific news since the second estimate that justifies a probability above the low 20s. Weighing group consensus, the empirical tug-of-war between realism and base rates, and the unique volatility of Q1, I am increasing my probability to 20%.

question_details.title: Will the third estimate of Q1 2025 annualized real GDP growth show an increase?

question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Bureau of Economic Analysis' Gross Domestic Product, 1st Quarter 2025 (Third Estimate) release shows that real gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate greater than 0.0%. ([BEA news releauses](https://www.bea.gov/news/current-releases))

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Forum for Competitiveness Maintains Growth Estimate Below 2% in 2025**
The Forum for Competitiveness maintains its estimate of a growth below 2% in 2025, due to the deterioration of external perspectives and the slowdown of private consumption in the first quarter, as announced today. According to the Forum's conjuncture note, 'the deterioration of external perspectives and the slowdown of private consumption, in addition to the very weak result of the first quarter, reinforce our expectation of a growth below 2% in 2025.' The Forum had previously estimated a downward revision of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for this year to values below 2%. The reduction of interest rates is expected to have a limited impact on investment, which is affected by 'weak expectations' of increased demand and high uncertainty. The difficulties in implementing the Recovery and Resilience Plan (PRR) are also a concern, with the expectation of its acceleration 'many times announced.' The deterioration of international perspectives is due to tariffs and their uncertainty, which paralyzes investment, hiring, and large purchases decisions. 'What seems more certain is that the ECB [European Central Bank] will continue to decrease its interest rates, one of the few positive aspects of the current situation, although we are getting closer to the end of these monetary stimuli,' pointed out. The ECB is expected to decide on a new 25 basis point cut in interest rates on Thursday, in a context still marked by commercial tensions and predictions of weak economic growth in the euro zone. The Forum also believes that the election result 'seems to guarantee some political stability in the short term,' highlighting that the main doubts are related to the Government's ability to approve the reforms that the economy needs.
Original language: pt

**Australian Economy Experiences Slower-Than-Expected Growth in First Quarter**
The Australian economy experienced a slower-than-expected growth in the first quarter of 2025, according to data from the Bureau of Statistics. The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 1.3% year-over-year, below the expected 1.5% but in line with the previous quarter's growth of 1.3%. However, the GDP grew by only 0.2% quarter-over-quarter, lower than the expected 0.4% and a slowdown from the 0.6% growth in the previous quarter. The weakness in government spending and the negative impacts of weather conditions, including cyclones and bushfires, have weighed on the growth. The weather conditions have particularly affected the mining, tourism, and maritime sectors. The government spending has remained largely stable, while household spending has increased at a slower pace than in the previous quarter. The disappointing results were partly anticipated by the mediocre data on the current account balance and net export contribution released on Tuesday. The Australian businesses have also reported lower operating profits during the quarter. The country's exports of raw materials have been affected by the new trade war between the US and China, one of its main export destinations. A de-escalation of the trade war in May could contribute to a better second quarter for the Australian economy. Although the Australian economy is still expected to grow this year, the Reserve Bank of Australia has warned that the growth will likely slow down, citing uncertainty about global trade. However, a slowdown in the economy gives the RBA more reasons to cut interest rates further, after having lowered them by a total of 50 basis points so far in 2025.

**Analysts Lower GDP Forecast Due to Economic Uncertainty**
Analysts surveyed by the Bank of Mexico (Banxico) have lowered their forecast for the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) due to the likelihood of economic contraction between the second and third quarters of the year, as well as public insecurity and a slower growth rate in the United States. The consensus of 44 economic analysis and consulting groups adjusted their estimate for the GDP this year from 0.20% to 0.18%. For 2026, the estimate was revised from 1.50% to 1.41%, while for 2027 it remained the same at 1.80%. However, the forecast improved for the next 10 years, reaching 1.85%. The analysts weighed both internal and external factors in a context of great local and global uncertainty. The incidence of public insecurity as a limiting factor for economic activity increased from 13.7% to 15.9%, while the uncertainty about the internal economic situation advanced from 5.4% to 9.8%. As a result, the consensus reduced the projection of the US GDP for the third time this year, from 1.70% to 1.45% for 2025. The lowest projection points to a minimum growth of 0.60%, while the highest projection is 2%.

**Forum for Competitiveness Maintains Growth Estimate Below 2% in 2025**
The Forum for Competitiveness maintains its estimate of a growth below 2% in 2025, due to the deterioration of external perspectives and the slowdown of private consumption in the first quarter, as announced today. According to the Forum's conjuncture note, 'the deterioration of external perspectives and the slowdown of private consumption, in addition to the very weak result of the first quarter, reinforce our expectation of a growth below 2% in 2025.' The Forum had previously estimated a downward revision of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for this year to values below 2%. The reduction of interest rates is expected to have a limited impact on investment, which is affected by 'weak expectations' of increased demand and high uncertainty. The difficulties in implementing the Recovery and Resilience Plan (PRR) are also a concern, with the expectation of its acceleration 'many times announced.' The deterioration of international perspectives is due to tariffs and their uncertainty, which paralyzes investment, hiring, and large purchases decisions. 'What seems more certain is that the ECB [European Central Bank] will continue to decrease its interest rates, one of the few positive aspects of the current situation, although we are getting closer to the end of these monetary stimuli,' pointed out. The ECB is expected to decide on a new 25 basis point cut in interest rates on Thursday, in a context still marked by commercial tensions and predictions of weak economic growth in the euro zone. The Forum also believes that the election result 'seems to guarantee some political stability in the short term,' highlighting that the main doubts are related to the Government's ability to approve the reforms that the economy needs.

**Australian Economy Experiences Slower-Than-Expected Growth in First Quarter**
The Australian economy experienced a slower-than-expected growth in the first quarter of 2025, according to data from the Bureau of Statistics. The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 1.3% year-over-year, below the expected 1.5% but in line with the previous quarter's growth of 1.3%. However, the GDP grew by only 0.2% quarter-over-quarter, lower than the expected 0.4% and a slowdown from the 0.6% growth in the previous quarter. The weakness in government spending and the negative impacts of weather conditions, including cyclones and bushfires, have weighed on the growth. The weather conditions have particularly affected the mining, tourism, and maritime sectors. The government spending has remained largely stable, while household spending has increased at a slower pace than in the previous quarter. The disappointing results were partly anticipated by the mediocre data on the current account balance and net export contribution released on Tuesday. The Australian businesses have also reported lower operating profits during the quarter. The country's exports of raw materials have been affected by the new trade war between the US and China, one of its main export destinations. A de-escalation of the trade war in May could contribute to a better second quarter for the Australian economy. Although the Australian economy is still expected to grow this year, the Reserve Bank of Australia has warned that the growth will likely slow down, citing uncertainty about global trade. However, a slowdown in the economy gives the RBA more reasons to cut interest rates further, after having lowered them by a total of 50 basis points so far in 2025.

**Argentina's Economy Shows Signs of Recovery, According to OECD Report**
According to the OECD, Argentina's economy began to recover in the third quarter of 2024, after a strong contraction in the first half of the year. The rebound was reflected in an annualized growth of 18% in that quarter, followed by a rise above 5% in the fourth quarter. In the fiscal area, the government achieved a financial surplus of 0.3% of GDP in 2024 and maintains its commitment to achieving a primary surplus in 2025. The monetary policy also changed, with the elimination of monetary emission and the adoption of a currency band regime that contemplates a monthly depreciation of 1%. The OECD projects an inflation rate of 36.6% for 2025, above the 29% previously estimated, but considers that the disinflation process will continue. For 2026, it expects a price increase of 14.9%, still high compared to the G20 average. The OECD also expects fixed investment to grow by 21.7% in 2025 and 14.9% in 2026, while exports will increase by 11.2% next year and 6.4% the following year. Imports will also rise, reflecting a recovery of purchasing power and a decrease in state intervention in trade. Despite the optimism, the OECD warns about certain structural challenges pending: a real exchange rate that could affect external competitiveness, the need to expand the tax base, reduce subsidies and fiscal distortions, and advance in a greater opening of the services sector. Finally, the report notes that the improvement in the business climate, the recovery of private sector credit, and the increased confidence of consumers mark a path of recovery that, although uncertain, shows positive signs in the medium term.

**Fed Expects 'One or Two' Interest Rate Cuts by End of Year**
The Federal Reserve (Fed) expects 'one or two' interest rate cuts by the end of the year, according to its meeting minutes from early May. The central bank estimated that the 'modal implied path based on option prices (...) decreased slightly during the period and was consistent with one or two 25-basis-point rate cuts by the end of the year, slightly more than in the March meeting'. The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), the body responsible for determining US monetary policy, left interest rates at their current range of 4.25-4.5% after its meeting on May 6 and 7, its third meeting of the year. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell noted that while it is 'likely' that tariffs will lead to higher inflation, slower economic growth, and higher unemployment if they continue, the economy remains solid for now. The minutes added that 'tariff announcements caused a significant deterioration in global risk perception, which largely reversed after a subsequent pause in the application of some tariffs and growing investor optimism about a decrease in trade tensions'. The publication comes a day before the US Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) releases its first revision of the first-quarter Gross Domestic Product (GDP). According to data released in late April, the GDP contracted 0.3% at an annualized rate from January to March, marking the first quarterly negative data since 2022. The Fed noted that the technical staff's projection of real GDP growth in 2025 and 2026 was weaker than in the March meeting, as announced trade policies implied a greater drag on activity. It was also expected that trade policies would lead to slower productivity growth and, therefore, reduce potential growth in the coming years. Participants in the central bank's meeting agreed that there is a possibility that inflation will be more persistent than expected, but also that the institution is well-positioned to make decisions without haste, awaiting 'greater clarity' on both price increases and economic activity.

**US Economy Contracts Under Trump's Leadership**
The US economy has contracted under the leadership of Donald Trump, according to the latest macroeconomic data. In the first quarter of 2025, the annualized GDP growth rate was negative, and the preferred inflation measure by the Fed has increased significantly. The initial estimate of the GDP growth rate for the first quarter of 2025, published by the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA), showed a decline of 0.3% in annualized terms. This result was different from the expectations of economists, who had expected a low reading and a clear decline compared to the previous quarter, but still expected a growth of 0.3%. The published reading is the worst result since the first quarter of 2022. The Americans present the GDP dynamics differently than the Europeans. They annualize short-term data, i.e., they convert it into annual data. In short, the monthly value is multiplied by 12, and the quarterly value by 4. The Fed's model from Atlanta also signaled a slowdown in the US economy. Its forecast, updated weekly, initially predicted a growth of over 2% in annualized terms, but from March, it began to indicate that the US economy would contract in the first quarter by nearly 3%. In the latest update on April 27, it predicted a decline of 2.7%. The economists also expected a weaker result due to the observed trend of building inventories and increased imports to the US before expected changes in trade policy. The 'Day of Liberation', when Donald Trump announced reciprocal tariffs, took place on April 2. The publication follows the Fed meeting on March 18-19, at which the decision-makers presented mixed perspectives on economic projections for the US. The GDP growth rate forecast for this year was significantly revised downward to 1.7% (from 2.1% expected in December). The mid-week data are one of the most important quarterly readings before the planned meeting of the Fed on May 6-7, as they include new data on inflation, according to the preferred measure of the Federal Reserve, PCE (Personal Consumption Expenditures). However, the statistics were not good, as the PCE measure in the first quarter jumped to 3.5% from 2.6% in the fourth quarter of 2024. It was also higher than the forecast, which expected a 3.3% increase in prices. The report also included the GDP deflator, which measures the inflation of all domestic goods and services, including exports, but excluding imports. It was expected to increase to 3.1% compared to 2.3% in the last three months of 2024. The actual result was also significantly higher and reached 3.7%.
